item.title: Monsoon rains collapse roof at Delhi airport, crushing cars and killing 1
item.dc:creator: Anant Gupta, Karishma Mehrotra
item.description: India has seen an infrastructure boom to meet rising demands for transportation but there have been criticisms about poor maintenance and oversight of building.

item.title: Why China’s Communist Party expelled two former defense ministers
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd
item.description: The tough language in the expulsion announcement suggests Chinese leader Xi Jinping is not done with his effort to ensure total loyalty in the world’s largest army.

item.title: Iran votes for a new president as the country faces multiple crises
item.dc:creator: Susannah George
item.description: For Iran’s ruling clerics, the public’s participation in elections is important to maintain the regime’s legitimacy, even as Iranians grow more disillusioned.

item.title: Post publisher’s role in hacking response comes into sharper focus
item.dc:creator: Aaron Davis, Greg Miller, Sarah Ellison, Isaac Stanley-Becker
item.description: Former U.K. prime minister Gordon Brown calls for William Lewis to be criminally investigated. Lewis says he “did nothing wrong.”

item.title: In France’s rebranded far right, flashes of antisemitism and racism persist
item.dc:creator: Anthony Faiola, Annabelle Timsit
item.description: Ahead of French elections, vitriol and innuendo from National Rally candidates amplify doubts about how much the party of Marine Le Pen has truly evolved.

item.title: The French far right is leading in election polls. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack
item.description: France’s far-right National Rally party hopes to win an outright majority in National Assembly elections that begin on Sunday.

item.title: The twilight of Macronism
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: In the upcoming parliamentary elections in France, no realistic scenario looks good for French President Emmanuel Macron.

item.title: Critically ill children leave Gaza in first evacuation in weeks
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
item.description: The evacuation was coordinated by Israel, Egypt and the United States and followed weeks of pressure on Israel to allow sick Palestinians to leave the enclave.

item.title: Gazans flee homes ahead of new Israeli operation in northern neighborhood
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit, Kareem Fahim, Sarah Dadouch
item.description: An Israel Defense Forces soldier was killed in Jenin, in the West Bank, when his vehicle was hit by a buried explosive, Israeli forces and media reported.

item.title: Iran is picking a new president. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth
item.description: Four men are now running for president in Friday’s vote. Only one is considered a reformist.

item.title: U.S. to receive first new pandas in 20 years after farewell party in China
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Pandas Yun Chuan and Xin Bao will set up home at the San Diego Zoo in California. An elaborate farewell ceremony was held in their honor in Sichuan, China.

item.title: China says U.S. can’t stop it from taking ‘giant steps’ in space
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Lyric Li
item.description: China is the first country to retrieve rocks from the far side of the moon, which experts say could be a game changer in understanding lunar history.

item.title: Neanderthal community cared for child with Down syndrome, fossil suggests
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: The bone of a 6-year-old found in Spain’s Valencia region provides evidence of communal care by Neanderthals, researchers say, and maybe even compassion.

item.title: A world-first emissions tax is going after gassy cattle
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: Denmark’s bill, which has broad consensus support, targets greenhouse gases emitted by the country’s cows, pigs and sheep. New Zealand axed plans for a similar tax.

item.title: What an election betting scandal says about British politics and culture
item.dc:creator: William Booth, Karla Adam
item.description: At least five Conservative officials are being investigated by Britain’s gambling watchdog as part of a probe into their placing bets on the timing of the British general election, which is set for July 4.

item.title: Bolivian soldiers storm plaza; former general accused of coup attempt
item.dc:creator: Susana López, Samantha Schmidt
item.description: A dismissed former Army general was accused of leading an uprising. President Luis Arce denounced the “irregular” troop movements in Plaza Murillo and said “democracy must be respected.”

item.title: U.S. war aid of $6.5 billion discussed during ‘productive’ Gallant visit
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung
item.description: Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant attempted to smooth turbulent public relations with Washington, amid conversations on military assistance and a transition to lower-intensity operations in Gaza.

item.title: Ex-Honduran president sentenced to 45 years for trafficking drugs to U.S.
item.dc:creator: Shayna Jacobs, Mary Beth Sheridan
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández was accused of running a ‘narco-state’ that helped send South American cocaine to the United States. He has maintained his innocence.

item.title: After protests, Kenya’s president backs down on controversial tax bill
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall, Rael Ombuor
item.description: President William Ruto’s rejection of the raft of tax hikes comes a day after several people died after clashes with the police during demonstrations.

item.title: Biden border restrictions bring sharp drop in illegal crossings
item.dc:creator: Nick Miroff
item.description: The number of migrants crossing the U.S. southern border illegally has dropped more than 40 percent in three weeks, officials said.

item.title: Israel blames U.N. for Gaza aid crisis amid fresh reports of starvation
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit, Anika Seth
item.description: About 500,000 Palestinians are on the brink of starvation, according to a report by U.N. agencies and aid groups.

item.title: Closed-door espionage trial of U.S. journalist kicks off in Russia
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, who the U.S. says is wrongfully detained, was arrested on a reporting trip over a year ago in Russia and faces 20 years in prison if convicted.

item.title: U.N.-approved, Kenya-led security force finally arrives in Haiti
item.dc:creator: Widlore Mérancourt, Amanda Coletta
item.description: The United States has recruited countries and led funding and logistics for the mission, but President Biden says he won’t send U.S. forces.
